title: A Deep Dive Into SeaTunnel Metadata Caching
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-22, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fhackernoon.com%2Fa-deep-dive-into-seatunnel-metadata-caching%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019be5640b3a-97a12639-0eb4-416a-a638-2131a44ac10c-000000/mQ3LTefabu2aG4l8se8FsKw0goVn3F5wYNwdkuqXKQM=441
summary: A Deep Dive Into SeaTunnel Metadata Caching (5 minute read) SeaTunnel Zeta addresses the major data integration bottlenecks of classloader conflicts, checkpoint overhead, and metadata request surges via intelligent metadata caching, distributed Hazelcast's IMap storage, and automated lifecycle management. Its shared classloader model reduces Metaspace use, while millisecond-level state access and asynchronous persistence decouple memory and backup, ensuring reliability in large-scale jobs.

title: Unconventional PostgreSQL Optimizations
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-22, Reading time: 11 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fhakibenita.com%2Fpostgresql-unconventional-optimizations%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019be5640b3a-97a12639-0eb4-416a-a638-2131a44ac10c-000000/XlWqJcZBFIILM_gCLdQHPDbI84OiZIDbaNIX__-rK90=441
summary: Unconventional PostgreSQL Optimizations (11 minute read) Unconventional PostgreSQL techniques can deliver big performance gains, such as skipping impossible scans using constraints, indexing only the expressions you actually query to shrink indexes, and enforcing uniqueness on large values with hash-backed constraints. Thoughtful schema and index design often beats the default habit of adding large B-tree indexes everywhere.

title: Prisma 7: Rust-Free Architecture and Performance Gains
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-22, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.infoq.com%2Fnews%2F2026%2F01%2Fprisma-7-performance%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019be5640b3a-97a12639-0eb4-416a-a638-2131a44ac10c-000000/btbULTBLJt7vYwIFu1s1-KvdEwyRu3_wcKM4IaiE8i0=441
summary: Prisma 7: Rust-Free Architecture and Performance Gains (3 minute read) Prisma, the TypeScript-first ORM, shifts away from Rust in its release 7.0, delivering a 90% reduction in bundle size and 3x faster query execution, while cutting CPU and memory loads. Generated code now resides outside node_modules, enabling faster, restart-free development workflows, and type generation is 70% quicker, evaluating 98% fewer types.

summary: Apple Developing AirTag-Sized AI Pin With Dual Cameras (2 minute read) Apple is reportedly working on a small, wearable AI pin equipped with multiple cameras, a speaker, and microphones. It will likely run the new Siri chatbot the company plans to unveil in iOS 27. Apple wants the final version of the pin to be about the same size as an AirTag but slightly thicker. The AI pin could be released as soon as 2027, but development is still in the early stages, and the product could be canceled.

Apple has designed the chatbot so that its underlying models can be swapped out over time. The company will initially use Google-powered systems.

title: Similarity Scores Are Not Enough For Matching
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-22, Reading time: 7 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.usetusk.ai%2Fresources%2Fsimilarity-scores-are-not-enough-for-matching%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019be59bb3fe-fdc5bab6-3ab9-43dc-b96b-cf0f94e7a428-000000/ovSsI4mSQCbrCVw9B2qY-h_WEWgxr8cWqUIJnFw18D4=439
summary: Similarity Scores Are Not Enough For Matching (7 minute read) Tusk found traditional similarity scoring insufficient for accurate matching in Tusk Drift, a CLI tool for test generation and matching. Instead, its team developed a system based on a prioritized cascade of constraints to eliminate obviously incorrect matches first. title: Can you slim macOS down?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-22, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Feclecticlight.co%2F2026%2F01%2F21%2Fcan-you-slim-macos-down%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019be59bb3fe-fdc5bab6-3ab9-43dc-b96b-cf0f94e7a428-000000/oWi8ku6qmb2QypmgGXgVA7NTCQw_zyk5NCTAgHyERIQ=439
summary: Can you slim macOS down? (6 minute read) macOS can be "slimmed down" by disabling its hundreds of background processes. For example, even when Time Machine is disabled, its processes are still scheduled and dispatched by inaccessible system services.

title: SDFlgs - The Log Field I'd Been Ignoring That Unlocked Attack Path Detection
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-22, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.huntress.com%2Fblog%2Fldap-active-directory-detection-part-three%3Futm_source=tldrinfosec/1/0100019be619f6bb-d58c16ae-c07d-4029-84c5-a5571612f3dc-000000/gbzvY47fnez-2Y0h-THFsjLlZYwDJTfQUt70WUyQpQE=441
summary: SDFlgs - The Log Field I'd Been Ignoring That Unlocked Attack Path Detection (8 minute read) SDFlags is a field that controls which security descriptor information is returned in queries and is used extensively in BloodHound and SharpHound. Querying for nTSecurityDescriptor fields (Owner, Group, DACL, or SACL) opens the door to attack path mapping. Conversely, legitimate tools almost never set SDFlags when running AD queries, opening up a new detection opportunity.

title: Scaling PostgreSQL to power 800 million ChatGPT users
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-23, Reading time: 14 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinks.tldrnewsletter.com%2FEO1VtL/1/0100019beac2a03d-f4864457-9a83-4365-bf24-2e78ef1288cc-000000/ehVcpLTlEJEWAMsAjgCygLuVGsUYUe7xtfVawGc1t4Y=441
summary: Scaling PostgreSQL to power 800 million ChatGPT users (14 minute read) OpenAI scaled PostgreSQL to support 800 million ChatGPT users and millions of queries per second for its predominantly read-heavy workloads. To achieve this, its team offloaded write-heavy operations to sharded systems like Azure Cosmos DB and implemented application and query optimizations. Their architecture uses a single primary Azure PostgreSQL instance and nearly 50 global read replicas.

title: Keeping 20,000 GPUs healthy
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-23, Reading time: 11 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fmodal.com%2Fblog%2Fgpu-health%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019beac2a03d-f4864457-9a83-4365-bf24-2e78ef1288cc-000000/-QVIM-T4e3QOlgGA3LDwhv7ez4wpmcoCkCzYHzBLbzY=441
summary: Keeping 20,000 GPUs healthy (11 minute read) Modal runs a globally distributed pool of over 20,000 GPUs across multiple cloud providers. Its approach begins with instance type testing and selection, evaluating performance and reliability differences between cloud hyperscalers. This is followed by machine image preparation and automated boot checks to guarantee GPU health before customer workloads begin. Throughout an instance's life, Modal performs continuous passive and active healthchecking.

summary: GenAI, The Snake Eating Its Own Tail (11 minute read) AI weakens the ecosystems it relies on. Models trained on human content extract value without attribution or revenue for creators. A proposed fix is pay-per-use AI, with source citations and revenue sharing, so creators, users, and AI companies all benefit.

title: How Binary Dependencies Work Across Different Languages
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-23, Reading time: 13 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fvlad.website%2Fhow-binary-dependencies-work%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/0100019bead24678-cc5db18d-2a26-4123-83e1-84f2d9c282b0-000000/zBGPFifr_-U1OHHa93g6dEBe-ly0uwYGazgexUngq4Y=441
summary: How Binary Dependencies Work Across Different Languages (13 minute read) Precompiled binary libraries can be called from higher-level languages through three main approaches: dynamic linking, dynamic loading via FFI, and dynamic linking using extension modules. These techniques differ in when symbol resolution happens and how data is converted, with extension modules offering the best performance and flexibility at the cost of more complex native code.

summary: Vibe-Kanban (GitHub Repo) Vibe Kanban is a workflow tool designed for an agent-driven development world. It helps engineers plan, coordinate, and review work done by AI coding agents rather than writing most code themselves. The tool centralizes agent configuration, supports parallel and sequential agent execution, enables fast review and dev server startup, and tracks task status across local or remote (SSH) projects.

summary: Compiling Scheme to WebAssembly (5 minute read) The Bob Scheme project was extended with a new compiler that lowers full Scheme directly to WebAssembly, using the WASM GC extension to support closures, cons cells, symbols, and garbage collection. summary: Against cleverness (11 minute read) As AI and other complex technologies spread, good design must focus on resilience, transparency, and recovery rather than blaming individuals or chasing peak performance. AI amplifies latent errors, deskills humans, and fails unpredictably, so systems should limit autonomy, preserve human accountability, define clear boundaries, and be designed to fail safely‚Äîaiming not for smarter systems, but wiser ones that understand their limits.

title: The Invisible Work
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-23, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fhvpandya.com%2Finvisible-work%3Futm_source=tldrdesign/1/0100019beb042bca-e83e8e8c-00ef-4ce4-a1cb-f741abefe227-000000/p6DSQZ7GfoP1yHDHeR8jQK8q5vhmfkoEuME9wEjAEp4=441
summary: The Invisible Work (8 minute read) The most important work in organizations is often invisible: the coordination, clarification, and judgment that keep projects from drifting into chaos but disappear once things run smoothly. Recognition follows visible outputs and simple narratives, so this quiet leadership is undervalued, making it crucial for people who do it to work under leaders who can recognize and protect the work that actually makes progress possible.

summary: Sirius (GitHub Repo) Sirius is a GPU-native SQL engine that plugs into existing query engines (currently DuckDB, with Doris ‚Äúcoming soon‚Äù) via Substrait, so teams can offload execution to GPUs without rewriting SQL or rebuilding the whole platform. Built on NVIDIA CUDA-X, it reports ~10x TPC-H (on SF=100) speedup at similar on-demand cost. Today, it accelerates a limited operator/type set (joins, group-bys, etc.; common scalar types) and falls back to CPU for unsupported features.

summary: Introduction to PostgreSQL Indexes (21 minute read) PostgreSQL indexes are database objects that speed up data access by allowing the system to read less from disk, mapping key values to physical row locations. While these provide speed benefits for queries, they introduce costs such as increased disk space, overhead on write operations, longer query planning times, and higher memory usage.

summary: Security Detections MCP (GitHub Repo) Security Detections MCP is an MCP server that enables LLMs to query a unified database of over 7,200 Sigma, Splunk ESCU, Elastic, and KQL security detection rules through natural language. The tool features SQLite FTS5-powered full-text search across detection fields, MITRE ATT&CK mapping, CVE coverage lookup, and process name filtering, with token-optimized analysis tools that reduce data transfer by 25x compared to traditional queries. summary: Bandjacks (GitHub Repo) Bandjacks is a comprehensive Cyber Threat Intel system that quickly extracts MITRE ATT&CK techniques from threat reports, builds a knowledge graph of threat actors, and utilizes LLM response caching for faster extraction, among other features.

summary: Microsoft gave FBI a set of BitLocker encryption keys to unlock suspects' laptops (3 minute read) The FBI has obtained a warrant compelling Microsoft to hand over BitLocker recovery keys for three seized laptops, allowing agents to decrypt the drives despite full‚Äëdisk encryption. BitLocker recovery keys are often stored in Microsoft's cloud, enabling lawful access but also raising privacy and security fears if the company or its keys are compromised.
